title: In defense of Trump's request for wall finance, Congressman is magnifying the foreign aid scheme.
text: Legislators do not want to blame the partial closure of the federal government, which is now the longest in American history. Therefore, following President Donald Tramp Jan 8, some Democratic Republicans targeted Nancy Belusi and Chuck Schommer to block support for the Trump Plan. The U.S. Republic of Richard Hudson, Republic of Concord, was among these critics. "Only last week, Democrats voted to give $54 billion in foreign aid. Each @POTUS@realDonaldTromp requests 10 cents of every dollar they want to give to foreign governments to go secure our borders and build a wall. Is that too much to ask?" The Hudson tweet after Trump's speech. According to the White House website, Trump requested $5.7 billion to build approximately 234 miles of the new steel barrier on the southern border, an increase of $4.1 billion over the Senate bill. Let us be clear: the experts, even the right-holders, agree that the request for the Trump or the Wall will not in itself be sufficient to secure the border. (Taxbayers for Common Sense, a non-partisan observer organization, called the Wall "waste" and the Kato Institute, a free think tank, last year said the Wall "will not work.") But let's put that aside and just consider Hudson's calculations and his description of the draft law that was passed by the Democratic-controlled United States House of Representatives in January 3. The Hudson tweet mischaracterizes both what it pays and what it supports. In general, the estimates of foreign aid spending sometimes vary according to the agencies and funds under consideration, according to the Council on External Relations. For example, the Board estimates aid at over $40 billion per year, and Economist reports that foreign aid levels remained at $35 billion for 2017 and 2018. In connection with the bill in question - Human Resources 21, which passed the House of Representatives but did not vote in the Senate - Factcheck.org and Washington Post noted that the $54 billion involved more than foreign aid. It also includes $16 billion for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The budget for the operations of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs usually includes a series of items, from Embassy security to Foreign Minister Mike Pompio's salary, which Stephen Ellis, Deputy Chief Taxpayer, told the general sense. So "it would be wrong" to mix the Ministry's funding with foreign aid funding, Elise Poletti Fuckett said in the e-mail. On January 26, 2021, in the North Carolina tweet, Secretary of State Ellen Marshall, Jenna Woodsworth stated, "She has won state-wide races more than anyone else is likely to be alive." • On February 1, 2012, the spokesman for Hudson Tatom Gibson admitted that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was listed in the number mentioned by Congressman, but did not explain why. "The point is that Democrats voted for tens of billions of dollars for this purpose - about $12 billion more than requested by the President - but they will not support President Trump's request for $5 billion to secure our own borders." If we subtract $16 billion from Hudson's claim to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, that leaves us with $38 billion in foreign aid spending. Trump's $5.7 billion request is about 15 percent of that demand. It's not exactly the idea of Democrats now into the assets of a $54 billion spending plan. It is misleading to consider the spending plan as a democratic proposal. Expenditure at the same level was proposed for the first time when Republicans controlled the house, as guaranteed by Factcheck.org and Washington Post in their stories. In June, the Council of Representatives ' Accreditation Committee approved a $54 billion draft law on governmental and external operations. In July, the Senate Appropriations Committee approved a similar budget of $54.4 billion. Our rule, Hudson, said, "Democracy voted to give $54 billion in foreign aid," and Trump asked for "10 cents of every dollar they want to give to foreign governments to go secure our borders and build a wall. Hudson has the point that Trump's request of $5.7 billion is much lower than the amount spent on foreign aid. However, he erred in including the regular funding of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in his claim for foreign aid funds. More importantly, his tweet is misleading by giving the impression that the spending plan was the idea of Democrats. We assess his claim mostly wrong.
